X.T: The Cult Of The Dead Cow
CHACS (Center for High Assurance Computer Systems)

BLIST.TITLE: Tools
BLIST.ITEM:
ratproxyhttps://code.google.com/archive/p/ratproxy/
enHTML: a passive audit tool to detect server security issues

skipfishhttps://code.google.com/archive/p/skipfish/
enHTML: an active audit tool to detect server security issues

DOM Snitchhttps://code.google.com/archive/p/domsnitch/
enHTML: heuritics to find security issues in client-side code

burpBurphttps://portswigger.net/
enHTMLhttps://blog.portswigger.net/feeds/posts/defaultRSS: a Web proxy allowing snooping, replayâ€¦(personal notes../notes/burp.html
enHTML)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A thorough analysis of setuid: the system calls, divergence between Solaris, Linux and FreeBSD, its pitfallsâ€¦
This is a basic presentation of the Trojan horse software which report private data to some miscreant companies.

X.T: The Linux Security "State of the Union"

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A list of some of the projects trying to improve Linux security. This list is interesting, but it misses too many projects and the article is much too optimistic: no Linux deficiency is described, the projects are not criticized.
The issues with the visual "Turing tests" used to impede bots of exploiting a Web service.

X.T: The Journey from Poacher to Gamekeeper

ARTICLE.COMMENT: When you turn from a black hat into a white hat, people tend to be suspicious.

X.T: Open Source Security: Still a Myth

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author explains why open source software is probably less secure than proprietary software. I agree that the "many eyeballs" is wrong for most open source code, only the most important applications have their code reviewed by several persons, but I also believe that most software companies are not allocating real resources to improve the security of their products.

X.T: A Sci-Fi Future Awaits the Court

ARTICLE.COMMENT: JohnRobert, future technologies and the "right to privacy".

X.T: Real Story of the Rogue Rootkit

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Why have the security companies not reported and fought against the Sony's rootkit?

X.T: Data Mining 101: Finding Subversives with Amazon Wishlists

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some data mining in the data that Amazon let us look atâ€¦

An answer to KevinKelly who pretends that anonymity is a bad idea for Internet and will be replaced by pseudo-anonymity (where the real name of the person is known by the site): the issue is in fact all about accountability, pseudo-anonymity is the same as no anonymity.

X.T: Big Risks Come in Small Packages

ARTICLE.COMMENT: It is easier and easier to be stolen of a huge amount of data. In some cases, the solution, once a device has been stolen, could be to remotely delete the data.
US Congress votes a law for personal data protection that will pre-empt the state laws which are stronger.
More and more people are trying to get some control on everyone's PC: DRM, spyware, adware, security features that does not work against some companies productsâ€¦
Schneier tries to explain why we should try to protect our privacy. But I find this article less convincing that his usual production, even if I fully agree with the message.

A clever way to use the customer to control the cash register employee, how the ATM fraud has been managed in the UK vs. the US, and software companies should be liable for the security defects of their products.
Put a Trojan on a USB key and drop this one on a parking lotâ€¦
How to know if the visitor of your site is a human or a robot?
Facebook has learned the hard way that it is not the real secrecy of privacy that matters, but the its perception.

X.T: Why Microsoft is wrong on Vista security

ARTICLE.COMMENT: McAfee explains that Microsoft impedes them to properly implement an antivirus in Vista.
Architectural artefacts remain much longer that the risk they were design to solve.
It is difficult to protect something which in the hands of the attacker.
Young users are better at choosing good passwords.

X.T: Secustick gives false sense of security

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The "secure" Secustick USB key appears to be totally broken.

X.T: How Security Companies Sucker Us With Lemons

ARTICLE.COMMENT: GeorgeAkerlof's theory (markets where the sellers have more information than the buyers result in being dominated by bad products) can be applied to security products.

X.T: Reverse engineering techniques to find security bugs: A...

ARTICLE.COMMENT: AlexSotirov explains the tools he is using to analyze Microsoft patches. He also describes the security features of Windows and how to try to bypass them.

X.T: Could a Caveman Do It? The Surprising Potential of Simple Attacks

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author explains that some simple brute force attacks can break a system. He gives the example of a wireless ad hoc network. The idea is interesting. But its conclusions (attacking 10% of the nodes may degrade the network performance from 10% to 60%) are not really convincing.
Some analysis on the spread of malicious Web pages, the percentage of vulnerable Web users, and Microsoft and Apple efficiency to fix security bugs.

X.T: The Xbox 360 Security System and its Weaknesses

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After describing the Xbox security gaps, how they have been fixed in the Xbox 360, MichaelSteil describes one of the security holes found in that new release.

X.T: How to Steal a Botnet and What Can Happen When You Do

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How the UCSB hijacked the Torpig botnet and an analysis of the data they were able to get from this.

X.T: Behind the China attacks on Google (FAQ)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some little information on the December attack of Google and other Silicon Valley companies. The Chinese government is suspected.

X.T: New Attack Uses Internet Explorer's Own Features Against It
X.ST: Microsoft investigating threat, considering patch, or offering guidance for protection

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Another IE security hole: combining URL Security Zones and file-sharing protocol to access local files.

X.ST: These companies and others say privacy erosion is inevitable--but they're making it so.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Market forces push companies to offer less and less privacy, and people gets used to this situation.
A description of search spam used to attract Internet users and infect them with malware.
A guy who got his Joomla! site hacked give some basic advice on how to restore it.

X.T: TechEd 2013: Live Demonstration: Hacker Tools You Should Know and Worry About

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some quick demos of some hacking tools.

X.T: Why It's Important to Publish the NSA Programs

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The efforts of NSA to ensure that they can eavesdrop on everyone's communication is degrading the security of the US.

X.T: Eliminate banner grabbing in Apache Tomcat
X.ST: Don't let your Tomcat installation be a cyber snitch

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to configure Apache Tomcat so it does not reveal its version. But the last screenshot still shows itâ€¦

X.T: Was YOUR vote counted? (feat. homomorphic encryption) - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to ensure that your vote is properly counted while it cannot be determinated who you voted for.

X.T: One Line of Code that Compromises Your Server
X.ST: The dangers of a simplistic session secret

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An explanation of the danger of a poor session secret and how to properly manage it.

X.T: OSS-Fuzz: Five Months Later, and Rewarding Projects

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The current status of OSS-Fuzz and Google wil offer rewards for onboarding new projets.
DOMato: a HTML/CSS/JavaScript fuzzer to detect bugs.
A method for generating a random easy-to-remember password.

X.T: So you want to be a web security researcher?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some advice on how to become a security researcher.

X.T: The rockstar hackers protecting you from the bad guys
X.ST: In their spare time, they hack Metallica. Their day job? To protect and serve.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some basic information about bug bounties and hacker events.

X.T: Triton is the worldâ€™s most murderous malware, and itâ€™s spreading
X.ST: The rogue code can disable safety systems designed to prevent catastrophic industrial accidents. It was discovered in the Middle East, but the hackers behind it are now targeting companies in North America and other parts of the world, too.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The subtitle says it all.

X.T: Unplugging From Digital Controls to Safeguard Power Grids
X.ST: Legislation passed by the U.S. House and Senate supports isolating power equipment to block cyber attacks

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Protecting the critical equipments by isolating them from the digital networks.
A description of DM Verity, the mechanism used to validate the integrity of the root file system on Chromebook, and its change from SHA1 to SHA256.

X.T: This could be Microsoft's most important product in 2020. If it works
X.ST: ElectionGuard isn't designed to make voting machines safe from hackers. It's meant to make hacking them pointless.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of ElectionGuard, an open-source voting machine from Microsoft.
A simplified description of how a VPN is working.
The title says it all.

X.T: How U.S. agencies' trust in untested software opened the door to hackers
X.ST: The government doesnâ€™t do much to verify the security of software from private contractors. And thatâ€™s how suspected Russian hackers got in.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: In the U.S., people have different opinions on how to avoid attacks done via third party software.
Reidentifying persons from anonymous location data.

X.T: In epic hack, Signal developer turns the tables on forensics firm Cellebrite
X.ST: Widely used forensic software can be exploited to infect investigators' computers.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: MoxieMarlinspike hacked Cellebrite, an application used by governments to break into phones.
A presentation of TPM.
A basic and naive presentation of EMV and contactless payment.
An overview by RSA Security of PKI main features: issuing certificates, revoking certificatesâ€¦
StevenLevy explains that the public key cryptography has been created inside a British intelligence agency, before being recreated by RonRivest, AdiShamir, and LeonardAdleman.
Two wires and four transistors to encrypt data.

X.ST: Swedes find vulnerability in supposedly secure quantum cryptography system

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A vulnerability has been found in the authentication phase.
A list of examples where cryptography has been improperly used. This is very enlightening: just do not do it yourself!
Yet another try to break GSM A5/1 encryption.

X.T: Flaw in the Enigma Code - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A high level description of how the Enigma code was broken.
RonRivest, the "R" of "RSA", describes the RSA-129 Factoring Challenge and its achievement.

X.T: Quantum Computing and Other Extras (with Ron Rivest) - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The continuation of the previous video.

X.T: How the United States Is Developing Post-Quantum Cryptography
X.ST: NIST has enlisted researchers from academia and private industry to get quantum-resistant cryptography ready for 2022

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: How to keep an open secret with mathematics.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of Shamir's Secret Sharing.

X.T: New Cryptography Method Promising Perfect Secrecy Is Met With Skepticism
X.ST: An international team claims its perfect secrecy cryptography is made unbreakable by physics

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A research team proposes to use reflective nanodisks and a laser to generate OTP, but the proposal is negatively criticized.

X.T: Codes secrets et magie avec Manu Houdart - Myriogon #8

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An explanation of the basic first cryptographic methods and a card trick.

X.T: Let's Crack Zodiac - Episode 5 - The 340 Is Solved!

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How the Zodiac cipher has been solved.

X.T: Un Ã©tudiant franÃ§ais cracke la NASA !

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The simple code used on Perseverance parachute.

X.T: Comment dÃ©chiffrer (presque) n'importe quel message codÃ© ? ðŸ”‘ðŸ”“ðŸ“œ

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A simple explanation about how to use Markov chain Monte CarloMarkov chain Monte Carlo to decrypt a message.

X.T: Markov Chain Monte Carlo, ou comment dÃ©chiffrer nâ€™importe quel code secret

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some information complementing the previous video.
A classical and basic presentation of cryptography.
A description of SHA1.
The continuation of the previous video.

X.T: Magic "Nothing Up My Sleeve" Numbers - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: About the choice of the magic numbers in cryptographic algorithms.
A description of Diffieâ€“Hellman key exchange.
A very simple explanation of the computations.
How to improve Diffieâ€“Hellman key exchange to avoid a man-in-the-middle attack.
A basic introduction to elliptic curves.
About the fact that Dual_EC_DRBG may be intentionally weak.

X.T: EXTRA BITS: Dual Elliptic Curve Backdoor - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The continuation of the previous video.
How Bletchley Park broke the Lorenz Cipher.

X.T: How Signal Instant Messaging Protocol Works (& WhatsApp etc) - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of Signal Protocol.
The continuation of the previous video.

X.T: What's Up With Group Messaging? - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Currently, the security is weaker for group messaging.
The title says it all.
A presentation of the ChaCha cipher.
A basic non-technical introduction to symmetric encryption and AES.

X.T: This Video was Not Encrypted with RSA | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to share the key when using symmetric encrypion and a short explanation of RSA.

X.T: The Mathematics of Diffie-Hellman Key Exchange | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The mathematics of Diffie-Hellman key exchange.

X.T: 10 prouesses de la cryptographie par Science4All - CRYPTO #01 - String Theory

ARTICLE.COMMENT: These cryptography subjects are described much too quickly.

X.T: La rÃ©volution Blockchain par Science4All - CRYPTO #03 - String Theory

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some proselytism about the blockchain, but there is no explanation of how it works.

X.T: Les 2 principes fondamentaux de la Blockchain par Science4All - CRYPTO #04 - String Theory

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very basic explanation of why the blockchain mechanism successfully works.

X.T: How can I get setuid shell scripts to work?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Since I'm fed up to explain my workmates that setuid scripts are a very bad idea, I now just send them this FAQ.

X.ST: (Trust-Relationship Exploitation)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This is a short summary of the TCP/IP protocol, how to perform IP spoofing and how to avoid it.
rfp explains how to break a web server because of insecure CGI Perl scripts: embedded nul, unescaped backslash and pipes commands.
PC Week proposed a challenge: break into their Linux server. This is a description of the winner method.
In this article, rfp explains some holes in IIS, Cold Fusion and MS SQL server (FYI, there are some problems with the HTML page, it is better to read the source).

X.T: Examining Remote OS Detection using LPD Querying

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to recognize an OS by sending malformed request to the lpd daemon.
This paper explains how to detect LKM rootkits.
A typical example of applying the methods described in the previous rain.forest.puppy's article.

X.T: The Dangers of Allowing Users to Post Images

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some CGI scripts allowing user to post images to not check the input, this can be used to execute some GET methods.

X.T: Search Engines as a Security Threat

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Search engines can help to find vulnerable servers or can be used as anonymous proxies.
SOAP::Lite is highly insecure: any loaded routine can be remotely called.

X.T: Linux kernel file offset pointer handling

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using a race condition on the file offset management to be able to read kernel memory.

X.T: Cache missing for fun and profit

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to measure the memory access times to analyze cache hits/misses and break a cryptographic key.

X.T: How To Break Web Software - A look at security vulnerabilities in web software

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After some general stuff about the Web, Mike describes how the security attacks are evolving and gives some examples of current common security holes: session hijacking, cross-site scripting, HTTP response splittingâ€¦ He also proposes the STRIDE (Spoofing, Tampering, Repudiation, Information disclosure, Denial of service, Escalation of privilege) framework to test Web applications.
After some stats on cybercriminals deeds, NeilDaswani describes SQL injection, cross-site request forgery (XSRF), and cross-site script inclusion (XSSI) and how to avoid them.

X.T: Bash specially-crafted environment variables code injection attack

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A bad Bash bug: it is possible to inject a command by putting it at the end of a function in an environment variable.

X.T: Detecting and exploiting path-relative stylesheet import (PRSSI) vulnerabilities

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Exploiting the fact that some frameworks handle a relative path to CSS files.
A simple explanation of the Key Reinstallation Attack.

X.T: How a Dorm Room Minecraft Scam Brought Down the Internet

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A non-technical, but detailed, story of the Mirai botnet.
Playing with combining marks, but there is no security gap to exploit here.
Using HTTP requests to get data from a speadsheet or from the local filesystem.
A tool to analyze the JavaScript objects of a browser.

X.T: Evading CSP with DOM-based dangling markup

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Exposing Intranets with reliable Browser-based Port scanning

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to scan ports with Chrome, Firefox and Edge.

X.T: XS-Searching Googleâ€™s bug tracker to find out vulnerable source code
X.ST: Or how side-channel timing attacks arenâ€™t that impractical

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using timing to extract information from monorail.
The description of a very old security hole found in scp.
The title says it all: injecting JavaScript expressions containing no parentheses nor semi-colons.

X.T: Provoking browser quirks with behavioural fuzzing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using fuzz testing to detect improper handling of some characters in the HTML parser and in the JavaScript parser.
Exploiting the fact that PayPal inserts a GET parameter in their CSP directive to override this one.

X.T: HTTP Desync Attacks: Request Smuggling Reborn

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to exploit the fact that servers of different layers handle invalid HTTP requests differently.

X.T: A look at the Windows 10 exploit Google Zero disclosed this week
X.ST: This privilege escalation vulnerability has lurked within Windows for 20 years.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A high-level description of the bug in MSCTF.DLL.

X.T: Forum cracks the vintage passwords of Ken Thompson and other Unix pioneers
X.ST: Security in the early days of Unix was poor. Then, there were the passwords.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Breaking the passwords from a 1980 BSD snapshot.
A high-level description of DNS poisoning.

X.T: The First Internet Worm (Morris Worm) - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Yet another telling of the Robert Morris Internet Worm, but this one does not go in the details.

X.T: The Internetâ€™s Most Notorious Botnet Has an Alarming New Trick
X.ST: The hackers behind TrickBot have begun probing victim PCs for vulnerable firmware, which would let them persist on devices undetected.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The bot is checking if the UEFI is vulnerable.

X.T: OpenSSL fixes high-severity flaw that allows hackers to crash servers
X.ST: The widely used code library is also purged of a certificate verification bypass.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Two bugs are fixed: a null pointer dereference and some conditions allowing to bypass the certificate verification.

X.T: 5 ways to prevent code injection in JavaScript and Node.js

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some basic information about code injection in JavaScript and an advertisement for Snyk.

X.T: Affaire Pegasus : comment des tÃ©lÃ©phones ont-ils pu Ãªtre contaminÃ©s sans action de leur propriÃ©taire ?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some information about how Pegasus works.

X.T: SolarWinds and the Holiday Bear Campaign: A Case Study for the Classroom

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overview of how Russia's SVR performed the SolarWinds attack.

X.T: Hacking et virus informatiques (dans le monde rÃ©el) bonus: Corewar! - Passe-science #43

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to buffer overflows and viruses.
Using invisible characters or homoglyphs to hide code instructions in JavaScript code.

X.T: How $323M in crypto was stolen from a blockchain bridge called Wormhole
X.ST: Cryptocurrency carries risk. Blockchain bridges heighten it.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Attackers can force Amazon Echos to hack themselves with self-issued commands
X.ST: Popular â€œsmartâ€ device follows commands issued by its own speaker. What could go wrong?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Linux has been bitten by its most high-severity vulnerability in years
X.ST: Dirty Pipe has the potential to smudge people using Linux and Linux derivitives.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of Dirty Pipe, an uninitialized variable allows an attacker to overwrite a file cached in memory.

X.T: First Microsoft, then Okta: New ransomware gang posts data from both
X.ST: If you haven't heard of Lapsus$, you have now. It probably won't be the last time.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Lapsus$, a new hacker group, claims to have hacked into Okta and Microsoft.
A basic, detailed, and slow description of a SQL injection attack.
SQL is too dangerous, it should not be used anymore.

X.T: Smashing The Stack For Fun And Profit
Smashing The Stack For Fun And Profit

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very well-known article: EliasLevyAleph One describes what is a buffer overflow exploit and how to exploit it.
At the beginning of Internet explosion, there were some major security issues: you could simply crash a machine by sending an illegal IP packetâ€¦

X.T: TAKING ADVANTAGE OF NON-TERMINATED ADJACENT MEMORY SPACES

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A small variation of the buffer overflow by using contiguous buffers.
Some new overflow techniques: overwriting the return address despite the presence of a canary, patching the atexit table and patching the global offset table.
Yet another buffer overflow technique: overwriting the VPTR table.

X.T: SHARED LIBRARY CALL REDIRECTION VIA ELF PLT INFECTION

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Silvio describes how to hijack the procedure linkage table (this is done by patching the executable).

X.T: Remotely Exploitable Buffer Overflow in Outlook "Malformed E-mail MIME Header" Vulnerability

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A nice buffer overflow in Outlook: no need to open an attachment or even to read the mail, you could be infected by a virusâ€¦ An exploit is provided.

X.T: JPEG COM Marker Processing Vulnerability in Netscape Browsers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A nice way to make Netscape execute code recorded in a JPEG file!
A buffer overflow in SmartDownload, no exploit provided.
A description of System V and GNU C malloc implementations with some way to generate and exploit overflow in the heap.

X.T: Vudo - An object superstitiously believed to embody magical powers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An impressive description of the sudo exploit (which uses a corruption of the heap) with a detailed analyzis of Doug Lea malloc library.

X.T: The advanced return-into-lib(c) exploits: PaX case study

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to circumvent OSes with a non executable stack by calling functions in the loaded shared libraries.
An idea still to be exploited, preloading a SIGSEGV event handler to redirect the program execution.
A description of the conditions necessary to create a shellcode which is a valid UTF8 string and some tricks to fulfill them.
How to exploit format string bugs to examine the stack and execute a root shell.

X.T: Write It Secure: Format Strings and Locale Filtering

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A non technical overview of format string exploit and locale hijacks.
A basic, yet effective, introduction to integer overflow/wrap around exploits.

X.T: Smashing The Kernel Stack For Fun And Profit

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An exploit for the select() OpenBSD signed/unsigned vulnerability.

X.T: Cross Site Scripting Info: Encoding Examples

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Same thing from the Apache group.

X.T: Understanding Malicious Content Mitigation for Web Developers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some advice to avoid cross-site scripting. But the problem is so complex that this is just an overview.

X.T: CERTÂ® Advisory CA-2000-02 Malicious HTML Tags Embedded in Client Web Requests

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This CERT Advisory is a basic presentation of the cross-site scripting vulnerability.

X.ST: Use a custom tag library to encode dynamic content

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After a quick presentation of some types of cross-site scripting attacks, the author describes how to easily avoid them in JSP by using a private tag.

X.T: Prevent cross-site request forgery: Know the hidden danger in your browser tabs
X.ST: Learn to prevent cross-site request forgery or your clients might do a hacker's bidding without knowing it

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.ST: Resource contention can be used against you

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some advice on avoiding race condition attacks when using files.

X.T: Delivering Signals for Fun and Profit
X.ST: Understanding, exploiting and preventing signal-handling related vulnerabilities.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Signal handlers are difficult to write correctly, so many of them can be exploited as security holes.
Bruce opinion is that a company should be considered responsible when one of its customer is victim of phishing.

X.T: Two Things That Bother Me About Google's New Firefox Extension

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Google's Firefox extension to flag phishing use unencrypted HTTP request, this may be a problem.

X.T: Identifying Suspicious URLs: An Application of Large-Scale Online Learning

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A study of several algorithms to automatically classify phishing vs. benign URLs.

X.T: Devious New Phishing Tactic Targets Tabs

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of a new kind of phishing attack: the tabnabbing, where a hidden type morphs into a phishing page to trap the inattentive user.
A clever way to use Web bugs: embed them in an Office document!
Even more clever, use the Web bugs to trace the forward and added text to an email you have sent.

X.T: Denial of Service via Algorithmic Complexity Attacks

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A DoS based on finding the worst case of use of a hash table, the authors propose their own version of a universal hashing to fix the issue.

X.T: Protect your Apache server from DoS attacks

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some information on Apache and DoS attacks, but this article is not very clear and informative.

X.T: About that hash flooding vulnerability in Node.jsâ€¦

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Yet another DoD attack by flooding a hash table. The V8 team had trouble to get a proper fix.

X.ST: "The Story of Alice and her Boss"

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The authors have created two PostScript files with the same MD5 checksum.

X.T: Enough With The Rainbow Tables: What You Need To Know About Secure Password Schemes

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Encoding passwords with as a simple MD5 checksum is a bad idea, Thomas suggests some better methods.
Using Google to break a MD5 checksum.

X.T: Predicting the winner of the 2008 US Presidential Elections using a Sony PlayStation 3

ARTICLE.COMMENT: "3D5 15 DEAD": the authors have created 12 meaningful PDF files with the same MD5 checksum.
A Chinese team has been able to divide the search space by 211. SHA-1's future starts to look like MD5's future.
Yet another white paper on AJAX security. The only interest here is that it describes possible issues with AJAX bridging.
Some generalities about AJAX security and the difficulty to test it.

X.T: Top 10 Ajax Security Holes and Driving Factors

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This is not a list of possible attacks, just random thoughts about where a malicious script could be injected.

A presentation of the attack and possible ways to exploit it.

A very basic, but clear, description of the problem.
The same for Meltdown. The author should have merged the two articles since they contain mostly the same words!
A simple explanation of the Spectre attack.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A basic and clear explanation of CPU optimizations and how Meltdown and Spectre exploit them.

X.T: Meltdown Redux: Intel Flaw Lets Hackers Siphon Secrets from Millions of PCs

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Other security attacks related to the speculative execution have been found in Intel's CPUs.
A simple exploit of the fact that the code does not check that files extracted for a Zip file are not in written in another directory.
A basic description of hyperthreading and how Port Smash works.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Timing CSS evaluation time of a page using jQuery(location.hash) to extract some information from the page.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The details of using the attack on redhat.com.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The first fix of log4j was not completeâ€¦
